G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is filed by the Plaintiff, Sarah Thompson, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, requesting that the Court modify the existing custody and visitation order entered on May 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as the child resides primarily with the Plaintiff in Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the existing custody order was entered in this Court.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The best interests of the child standard is the paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody cases. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal/custody disputes the best interests of the child are the controlling consideration, and interprets the governing statute as requiring that removal be in the child’s best interests. While Yannas focuses on removal, it is doing so within the broader custody framework and repeatedly characterizes the child’s best interests as the paramount concern, so it is validly cited for that general Massachusetts custody principle.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ … The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The best interests of the child standard is the paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody cases. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under G. L. c. 208, § 30, removal may be ordered only if it is in the children’s best interests, and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the children’s best interests as the governing standard. Although the case is a removal/relocation dispute rather than an initial custody award, it treats the best interests of the child as the controlling, paramount consideration in deciding whether to alter custodial arrangements. This aligns with the proposition that the best interests standard is paramount in Massachusetts custody-related decisions.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents… Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests. … We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances…. … [T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The best interests of the child standard is the paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody cases. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody matters “the touchstone inquiry” is what is best for the child, and then applies that standard in determining physical custody. The court cites prior Massachusetts custody precedents and discusses that the judge must weigh all relevant factors in determining the child’s best interests, making clear that the best interests of the child standard is the controlling, paramount consideration in Massachusetts custody determinations.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child”…. ’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”}

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The planned relocation by the Defendant constitutes a significant disruption to the original assumptions underlying the parenting plan, and the Court has long held that the impact of such relocations can justify modification of custody orders when the child's best interests are affected. See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Kindregan v. Kindregan*, 377 Mass. 272 (1979).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde is a custody/visitation and property-division case; it does not involve a parental relocation or modification of an existing custody order based on relocation. The opinion focuses on initial custody determination, best-interests analysis, and the appropriateness of joint custody versus sole custody, without discussing moves, disruption of a parenting plan, or modification standards tied to relocation. Citing Rolde for the specific principle that relocation constitutes a significant disruption justifying modification of custody mischaracterizes its holding.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

*Kindregan v. Kindregan*, 377 Mass. 272.proposition: The planned relocation by the Defendant constitutes a significant disruption to the original assumptions underlying the parenting plan, and the Court has long held that the impact of such relocations can justify modification of custody orders when the child's best interests are affected. See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Kindregan v. Kindregan*, 377 Mass. 272 (1979).
*Kindregan v. Kindregan*, 377 Mass. 272.support_reasoning: Kindregan v. Kindregan does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or parental relocation. It concerns the standards and procedures for a guardian’s commitment of a mentally ill ward to a mental health facility, focusing on the ‘best interests’ standard and likelihood of serious harm. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that a parent’s planned relocation can justify modification of custody orders based on the child’s best interests.
*Kindregan v. Kindregan*, 377 Mass. 272.relevant_excerpt: "In other contexts we have upheld the application of a 'best interests' standard. Custody of a Minor, 375 Mass. 733, 753 (1978) (medical treatment). Petition of the New England Home for Little Wanderers to Dispense with Consent to Adoption, 367 Mass. 631, 646 (1975) (adoption)." (p. 280-281). This reference to “custody” is in the context of medical treatment and adoption, not relocation or modification of parenting plans.

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.proposition: A midweek overnight visit, requiring Emily to travel 90 minutes each way, undermines her stability and conflicts with her educational and social commitments. Massachusetts courts recognize that preserving a child's stability is critical in custody arrangements. See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (1987).
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does emphasize the children’s roots, adaptation, and support systems in Amherst as part of the best‑interests analysis, which reflects a general concern for stability. However, the case does not discuss midweek or long‑distance visitation schedules, travel burdens, or conflicts with educational or social commitments. It therefore cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition that a 90‑minute midweek overnight undermines stability; at most it provides only broad, background support for the general importance of stability in custody decisions.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “He has now been in Amherst since January, 1986, and he has spent most of his life there. He has been attending the Amherst school system and has adapted well. He, too, has a support system in place, including friends, doctors, and relatives. The judge placed a good deal of weight on the very close relationship between Rosemary and Tony. He found that both children are better off together, other factors being equal.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Plaintiff's proposed schedule reflects a reasonable, child-focused adjustment that prioritizes Emily's well-being and stability, consistent with the best interests standard. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not speak to the specific schedule for a child named Emily, but it does affirm the broader legal principle that custody and parenting-time arrangements must be structured around the child’s best interests, with attention to stability, continuity, and preserving important parent‑child relationships. The SJC approves a detailed, seasonally adjusted schedule that balances school‑week stability with substantial time with the non‑primary parent, expressly as a child‑focused application of the best‑interests standard. That general reasoning can be cited to support the characterization of a similarly structured, stability‑oriented schedule as reasonable and child‑focused, though the support is indirect rather than fact‑specific.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded legal custody of Kali to the mother, and divided physical custody between the father and the mother corresponding with the school year and vacations…. The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child…. Kali is to spend school weekdays with her mother because her mother’s schedule was sufficiently flexible to ensure that Kali’s needs during those periods will be attended to… To the same end, the order provides that Kali is to spend most school year weekends with her father….”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Plaintiff's proposed schedule reflects a reasonable, child-focused adjustment that prioritizes Emily's well-being and stability, consistent with the best interests standard. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a parenting-time schedule that is a reasonable, child-focused adjustment promoting stability and best interests. Custody of Vaughn does not discuss or endorse any particular schedule or adjustment as “reasonable” or “child-focused”; instead, it reverses and remands because the judge failed to make explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child when awarding custody. While the case reinforces that custody and visitation decisions must consider the impact of domestic violence on the child’s best interests, it does not provide authority for the specific claim that a given proposed schedule is a reasonable, stability‑promoting arrangement.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.proposition: The Plaintiff further requests that the Court consider the reduced ability of the current schedule to promote Emily's mental health and emotional well-being, which is paramount in any custody modification proceeding. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1982); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the standard governing removal/custody-related decisions and explains that the “best interests” analysis must include the emotional well-being of the custodial parent and the family unit as a whole, not just visitation logistics. It expressly refers to the “emotional well-being of the family unit” and the “emotional costs” imposed on the custodial parent, linking those considerations to the children’s best interests. That directly supports citing Hale for the proposition that a child’s mental health and emotional well-being are paramount factors in custody/removal decisions.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent… We conclude that… we cannot ascertain whether [the judge] also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..proposition: The Plaintiff further requests that the Court consider the reduced ability of the current schedule to promote Emily's mental health and emotional well-being, which is paramount in any custody modification proceeding. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1982); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007).
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the principle that a child’s mental health and emotional well‑being are paramount in custody modification proceedings. Guardianship of Estelle deals with a guardianship dispute and the constitutional requirement that a fit parent is entitled to custody absent a finding of unfitness; it does not articulate or emphasize that mental health/emotional well‑being are ‘paramount’ in custody modification. While the opinion discusses best interests and potential psychological harm, its holding is about the necessity of a clear fitness determination, not about prioritizing mental health in a custody modification framework. Thus it is not an accurate authority for the stated proposition.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The question, then, is how to balance a parent’s capacity to care adequately for a child (i.e., his or her ‘fitness’) with that child’s ‘best interests,’ given the child’s current circumstances. … At the same time, the ‘best interests of the child’ is the touchstone of the analysis. … Here, a key factual question for resolution is whether the father is fit to parent this particular child in light of the lengthy period during which she has been raised by, and has bonded with, the uncle and aunt….”
